White House aide Kellyanne Conway attempted to defend President Donald Trump's executive order banning travel from seven Muslim-majority countries by citing a "massacre" that never happened. 
"I bet it's brand new information to people that President Obama had a six-month ban on the Iraqi refugee program after two Iraqis came here to this country, were radicalized and they were the masterminds behind the Bowling Green massacre," Conway, a senior adviser to the president, said in an interview with MSNBC'S Chris Matthews on "Hardball" Thursday night. 
"Most people don't know that because it didn't get covered," she added. 
[ REPORT: Trump Team Looks to Rename Counterterror Program to Focus on Muslims ] 
However, it did not get covered because no such massacre occurred. 
What Conway was likely referring to was the 2011 arrest of two men from Iraq who had attempted to send weapons and money to al-Qaida fighters involved in the insurgency in their home country. They were living in Kentucky and their case was investigated out of the Bowling Green FBI office. 
Both men pleaded guilty to federal terrorism charges: Mohanad Shareef Hammadi was sentenced to life in federal prison, and Waad Ramadan Alwan received a 31- to 40-year sentence. 
Conway admitted her mistake on Twitter Friday morning, writing that she "meant to say 'Bowling Green terrorists'" – but not before Twitter mercilessly mocked her for the error. Saddened and sickened by Frederick Douglass' silence surrounding the Bowling Green Massacre. — Natasha Rothwell (@natasharothwell) February 3, 2017 Thank you, @KellyannePolls for reminding us about the famous Bowling Green Massacre, which occurred on February 30th at 13:00. — Mike Drucker (@MikeDrucker) February 3, 2017 RIP, 3-5 million illegal voters lost in the Bowling Green Massacre. #BowlingGreenMassacre — Michael Beeman (@MichaelBeeman) February 3, 2017 Oh, it was covered alright. https://t.co/Bc8K0wE8Hn via @BleacherReport — Jeremy Harlan (@jerharlanCNN) February 3, 2017 
While Conway and others in the administration have repeatedly cited a six-month ban under President Barack Obama on Iraqi refugees, fact checkers have found distinctions between the comparisons between a 2011 change in policy and Trump's order last month to stretch the truth. 
After Hammadi and Alwan were arrested, the Obama administration imposed more extensive background checks on Iraqi refugees, which slowed the processing and visa approvals, but never issued a blanket ban on immigrants from Iraq. 
During 2010, 18,251 Iraqi refugees were resettled in the U.S.; there were 6,339 in 2011 – a significant drop but not an outright stoppage – and 16,369 in 2012, according to State Department records.
